The Separation of Powers Act allows for the courts to reclaim their authority by reviewing agency actions under a de novo standard, so that judges can consider such issues solely on the merits. This removes the presumptive influences of agencies.

Mandated deference to agencies in the judicial review process hands agencies a tremendous power over the meaning of our laws, despite federal agencies not deriving their authority from the Constitution.

Chevron Deference requires that federal courts defer to statutory interpretations offered by federal agencies. The Constitution clearly gives the legislative power to Congress and judicial authority to the federal courts, not the bureaucracy.

It‚Äôs time to shrink the arsenal of an out-of-control federal bureaucracy, which is why I introduced H.R. 7895, the Separation of Powers Act. It would eliminate the judicial doctrine known as Chevron Deference, which empowers the federal bureaucracy.
